questions.text: Causes of antepartum haemorrhage include all of the following except: Options:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Antepartum haemorrhage (APH) is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract after the 28th week of pregnancy but before the birth of the baby. Incomplete abortion is characterized by bleeding that occurs before the age of viability, typically before 20-22 weeks of gestation, and therefore is not considered a cause of antepartum haemorrhage.

Causes of APH include:

  • Abruption: The most common cause.
  • Previa (Placenta Previa): The second most common cause.
  • Rupture of vasa previa.
  • Circumvallate placenta.
  • Local lesions: such as cervical polyp, Ca cervix (cervical carcinoma), varicose veins, or local trauma.

Explanation of Other Options:

Placenta Previa (Option A): Placenta previa is a well-known major cause of antepartum haemorrhage, where the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment, partially or completely covering the internal cervical os.

Ca cervix (Option B): Carcinoma of the cervix is a local lesion that can cause bleeding from the genital tract during pregnancy, thus being a cause of antepartum haemorrhage.

Vasa Previa (Option D): Vasa previa involves fetal blood vessels crossing or running in close proximity to the internal os, unprotected by placental tissue or umbilical cord. Their rupture can lead to severe antepartum haemorrhage, which is very dangerous for the fetus.

Key Takeaways:

  • Antepartum haemorrhage refers to bleeding in late pregnancy (after 28 weeks gestation).
  • Incomplete abortion is a cause of bleeding in early pregnancy (before viability) and is therefore not categorized as antepartum haemorrhage.
  • Common causes of APH include placenta previa, placental abruption, vasa previa, and local genital tract lesions like cervical cancer.

questions.text: Incidence of placenta previa is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The incidence of placenta previa is 1 in 200 pregnancies, which translates to 0.5%. It accounts for about one-third of all cases of antepartum hemorrhage.

  • In 80% of cases, placenta previa is found in multiparous women.
  • The incidence is increased beyond the age of 35 years, with high birth order pregnancies and in multiple pregnancies.

Key Takeaways:

  • The incidence of placenta previa is 0.5% (1 in 200 pregnancies).
  • It is a significant cause of antepartum hemorrhage, more common in multiparous women, and its incidence increases with maternal age, high birth order, and multiple pregnancies.

questions.text: Regimen used for expectant management of placenta previa is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Mcafee regime (or Mcafee and Johnson's expectant management) is the regimen advocated for the expectant treatment of placenta previa. The primary aim of this approach is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health.

Components of the Mcafee regime include:

  • Admission to the hospital and strict bed rest.
  • Monitoring of maternal vital signs.
  • Monitoring for fetal heart rate (FHR) and vaginal bleeding.
  • Administration of steroids for fetal lung maturation (contraindicated in chorioamnionitis).
  • Tocolysis (e.g., Nifedipine) if uterine contractions are present.
  • Administration of Anti-D immunoglobulin if the mother is Rh negative.
  • Blood transfusion if necessary due to significant bleeding.

Explanation of Other Options:

Zuspan regimen (Option A): The Zuspan regimen is associated with magnesium sulfate protocols, often used for preeclampsia management or tocolysis, not specifically for expectant management of placenta previa.

Brandt Andrews regime (Option C): The Brandt-Andrews maneuver is a method for controlled cord traction during the third stage of labor to aid in placental delivery, not a management regimen for placenta previa.

Chadwick regime (Option D): The Chadwick sign refers to the bluish discoloration of the cervix and vagina observed in early pregnancy.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Mcafee regime is the recognized protocol for the expectant management of placenta previa, focusing on prolonging pregnancy for fetal maturity while closely monitoring maternal and fetal well-being.
  • This involves hospitalization, bed rest, vigilant monitoring, and interventions like steroids and tocolysis as needed.

questions.text: All of the following are high risk factors for placenta previa except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primigravida (a woman pregnant for the first time) is generally not considered a high-risk factor for placenta previa. Instead, multiparity (having had previous pregnancies) is a known risk factor.

  • Risk factors for placenta previa include:
    • Multiparity
    • Advanced maternal age (35 years or older)
    • Smoking
    • Prior Cesarean delivery
    • Multifetal gestation (e.g., twins, triplets)
    • Placental abnormality
    • Prior curettage
    • History of ART (assisted reproductive technology)

Explanation of Other Options:

Age >35 years (Option B): Advanced maternal age (35 years or older) is a well-established high-risk factor for placenta previa.

Smoking (Option C): Smoking is a known risk factor that increases the likelihood of developing placenta previa.

Multifetal gestation (Option D): Multifetal gestation (e.g., twin or triplet pregnancies) is also a high-risk factor for placenta previa, as a larger placental mass increases the chance of low implantation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Primigravida is NOT a risk factor for placenta previa; multiparity is.
  • Key high-risk factors for placenta previa include advanced maternal age, prior Cesarean delivery, smoking, and multifetal gestation.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as mild degree of placenta previa?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Placenta previa is classified into different types based on the degree of placental extension into the lower uterine segment. For clinical purposes, these types are often graded into mild degree and major degree. Type I (anterior and posterior) and Type II anterior are classified as a mild degree of placenta previa.

  • There are four types of placenta previa depending on the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment.
  • For clinical purposes, the types are graded into:
    • Mild degree: Type-I and Type-II anterior.
    • Major degree: Type-II posterior, Type III, and Type IV. (Option B, C and D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Placenta previa is categorized into mild and major degrees.
  • Type I (anterior and posterior) and Type II anterior are considered mild degrees.
  • Type II posterior, Type III, and Type IV are considered major degrees.

questions.text: According to ultrasound identify type of placenta in following image:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the image, the placenta's lower margin is encroaching onto the lower uterine segment but does not reach or cover the internal os. This description perfectly matches the definition of a Type-I (Low-lying) placenta previa.

  • Type-I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type-II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type-III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type-IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

Explanation of Other Options:

No previa (Option A): This would mean the placenta is entirely in the upper uterine segment, which is not what the image depicts.

Marginal placenta previa (Option C): Marginal previa (Type II) would show the placenta reaching the edge of the internal os, which is a step beyond what is seen in the image. The image shows the placenta near the os but not quite at the margin.

Incomplete placenta previa (Option D): Incomplete previa (Type III) indicates the placenta partially covers the internal os. The image clearly shows the os uncovered by the placenta.

Key Takeaways:

  • The classification of placenta previa depends on the relationship of the placental edge to the internal cervical os.
  • A low-lying placenta (Type I) is characterized by the placenta encroaching into the lower segment but not reaching the internal os.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G4P3, previous 3 vaginal delivery comes to emergency at 38 weeks of gestation with an episode of bleeding. Bleeding was not associated with pain. On examination her pulse is 80bpm, BP 110/70 mmHg. Uterus is relaxed, FHS 130 bpm regular and there was no bleeding at the time. Immediate ultrasound was done for localization of placenta. Placenta is seen covering the internal OS on TVS. Which of the following is best for her?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient is at 38 weeks gestation and the ultrasound shows the placenta covering the internal os, which indicates a complete (or central/total) placenta previa. This condition is a definite indication for Cesarean section as vaginal delivery would lead to severe hemorrhage due to placental separation from the lower uterine segment as the cervix dilates.

  • In cases of placenta previa, the mode of delivery is Cesarean section.
  • The timing of delivery in uncomplicated cases of placenta previa is typically by 37 weeks.
  • Expectant management is not advised for a full-term pregnancy (38 weeks), especially when the placenta is covering the os. It's also not appropriate if the patient is in labor or has severe bleeding.

Explanation of Other Options:

Expectant management (Option A): Expectant management is used for earlier gestations (e.g., before 37 weeks) to allow for fetal lung maturity in cases of stable bleeding. At 38 weeks with a complete placenta previa, the pregnancy is at term, and immediate delivery via Cesarean section is indicated.

Induction of labour (Option C): Induction of labor is contraindicated in complete placenta previa because uterine contractions would cause the cervix to dilate, leading to placental detachment and potentially life-threatening hemorrhage for both mother and fetus.

Artificial rupture of membrane (Option D): Artificial rupture of membranes (AROM) is contraindicated in placenta previa, as it would directly expose the placenta to rupture, causing severe bleeding.

Key Takeaways:

  • A placenta covering the internal os (complete placenta previa) at term is a contraindication to vaginal delivery.
  • The definitive management for complete placenta previa at term is Cesarean section to prevent catastrophic hemorrhage.
  • Expectant management, labor induction, and AROM are inappropriate and dangerous in this scenario.

choices.text: Allow to go in spontaneous labour

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is noted to have a marginal placenta previa on an USG done at 28 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When a marginal placenta previa is diagnosed at 28 weeks of gestation, the most appropriate management is to repeat the ultrasound at 32-34 weeks. This is because a significant number of placenta previas diagnosed in the second trimester resolve spontaneously as the lower uterine segment lengthens and due to trophotropism (the growth of trophoblastic tissue towards the fundus).

  • Transvaginal sonography is the most accurate sonographic method to identify previa and is safe even with vaginal bleeding.
  • With the progressive increase in the length of the lower uterine segment, the lower placental edge relocates away from the cervical os, also due to trophotropism (growth of trophoblastic tissue towards the fundus), leading to resolution of placenta previa.
  • Therefore, if previa is diagnosed in the 2nd trimester, a repeat TVS is done at 32 weeks (or 32-34 weeks) to confirm the diagnosis of previa.

Explanation of Other Options:

Plan caesarean at 37 weeks (Option B): Planning a Cesarean section at 37 weeks is premature when a marginal previa is diagnosed at 28 weeks, as there is a high chance of resolution. A Cesarean section would only be planned if the previa persists and remains significant at a later gestation.

Allow to go in spontaneous labour (Option C): Allowing a patient with a confirmed placenta previa (even if marginal and persistent) to go into spontaneous labor can be dangerous, as it may lead to severe bleeding. The mode of delivery depends on the final placental location closer to term.

Give steroids for lung maturity (Option D): Giving steroids for lung maturity is appropriate if there is a risk of preterm delivery (e.g., due to significant bleeding from the previa), but it is not the primary or initial management for a stable marginal previa discovered at 28 weeks. The first step is to reassess its position.

Key Takeaways:

  • Many cases of placenta previa diagnosed in the second trimester resolve spontaneously.
  • Therefore, the initial management for a marginal previa at 28 weeks is expectant, involving a repeat ultrasound at a later gestation (32-34 weeks) to assess for resolution.
  • Interventions like planned Cesarean sections or steroid administration are considered only if the previa persists or if complications arise.

choices.text: Multiple bleeding episodes can lead to foetal anaemia and hypoxia
Smoking causes placental hypertrophy, thus risk of low lying placenta is increased
Stall worthy's sign is more commonly seen in anterior low lying placenta

questions.text: About placenta previa, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Smoking causes placental hypertrophy as a compensatory mechanism for carbon monoxide induced hypoxemia. This increased placental size can increase the risk of the placenta implanting or extending into the lower uterine segment, leading to a low-lying placenta or placenta previa.

  • In later months of pregnancy, as the lower segment progressively dilates and the inelastic placenta is sheared off the wall of the lower segment, bleeding episodes occur. The blood in these episodes is almost always maternal, thus fetal anemia cannot occur directly from these maternal bleeding episodes.
  • Stallworthy's sign is the slowing of the fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which promptly recovers as the pressure is released. This sign is suggestive of a low-lying placenta, especially of the posterior type, not commonly anterior.

Explanation of Other Options: Multiple bleeding episodes can lead to foetal anaemia and hypoxia (Option A): This statement is false. Bleeding in placenta previa is almost entirely maternal in origin. Fetal bleeding (and thus anemia and hypoxia) is usually associated with conditions like vasa previa or significant placental abruption, not typical placenta previa bleeding. Stall worthy's sign is more commonly seen in anterior low lying placenta (Option C): This statement is false. Stallworthy's sign is more commonly associated with a posterior low-lying placenta.

Key Takeaways:

  • Smoking is a risk factor for placenta previa due to compensatory placental hypertrophy.
  • Bleeding in placenta previa is predominantly maternal blood, not fetal blood.
  • Stallworthy's sign is a clinical indicator for low-lying placenta, particularly the posterior type.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida comes to the labour room with an episode of bleeding. She is 32 weeks pregnant. She complains of mild vaginal bleeding which was painless in nature. On examination her pulse: 82/min, BP: 110/70mmHg. Fetus is in transverse lie with FHS: 130 bpm. She denies any abdominal pain and the uterus is relaxed. Most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis in this patient is placenta previa given the classic presentation. The key features pointing to this are painless vaginal bleeding, a relaxed and non-tender uterus, and a non-compromised fetus (normal FHS). The transverse lie of the fetus can also be associated with placenta previa.

Clinical features of previa:

  • Painless, causeless, and recurrent vaginal bleeding (fresh red blood).
  • Bleeding is always revealed and proportionate to visible blood loss.
  • Uterus is proportionate to gestation age and relaxed.
  • Abdomen is non-tender.
  • Fetus is not compromised (unlike abruption and vasa previa).

Explanation of Other Options:

Vasa previa (Option A): While vasa previa also causes painless bleeding, it is typically characterized by fetal compromise (e.g., severe fetal heart rate decelerations, bradycardia) because the bleeding is of fetal origin, which is not noted here (FHS 130 bpm regular).

Abruptio placenta (Option C): Abruptio placenta (placental abruption) typically presents with painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and a tender, rigid uterus due to uterine contractions and concealed hemorrhage. Fetal distress is also common. These features are absent in the patient's presentation.

Show (Option D): "Show" refers to the passage of a small amount of blood-tinged mucus, usually indicating the onset of labor. While it involves bleeding, it's typically minimal, mucoid, and associated with cervical changes, not a significant "episode of bleeding" at 32 weeks without other signs of labor.

Key Takeaways:

  • Painless vaginal bleeding, a relaxed uterus, and a non-distressed fetus are the classic triad for placenta previa.
  • Other conditions like abruption and vasa previa have distinct clinical presentations (pain, uterine rigidity, fetal compromise).

choices.text: More than one bleeding episode in a month

questions.text: Mcafee and Johnson regime for placenta previa is not done in case of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Mcafee and Johnson regime for expectant management of placenta previa is primarily aimed at prolonging pregnancy to achieve fetal maturity. Therefore, it is not done when the gestational age is more than 37 weeks, as at this point, the fetus is considered at term, and the risks of continuing the pregnancy (especially with placenta previa) often outweigh the benefits of further gestation.

  • Expectant treatment in previa (Mcafee and Johnson) has vital prerequisites:
    • Availability of blood for transfusion whenever required.
    • Facilities for Cesarean section should be available throughout 24 hours, should it prove necessary.
  • Suitable cases for expectant management are:
    • Mother is in good health status (hemoglobin > 10 g%; hematocrit > 30%).
    • Duration of pregnancy is less than 37 weeks.
    • Active vaginal bleeding is absent.
    • Fetal well-being is assured (CTG and USG).

Explanation of Other Options:

More than one bleeding episode in a month (Option A): While frequent or severe bleeding episodes might prompt reconsideration or termination of expectant management, the explanation explicitly lists "Active vaginal bleeding is absent" as a suitability criterion for expectant management. Therefore, the presence of more than one bleeding episode would generally make expectant management less suitable or even contraindicated, meaning this is a case where it's not done.

Multiple pregnancy (Option C): Multiple pregnancy is often associated with a higher risk of complications in placenta previa and might influence the duration or intensity of expectant management, but it's not a direct exclusion criterion as clear as being beyond 37 weeks. However, the decision in multiple pregnancies would be more nuanced and generally geared towards delivery once fetal maturity is achieved.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Mcafee and Johnson regime for expectant management of placenta previa is specifically indicated for pregnancies less than 37 weeks where fetal maturity has not yet been achieved and the mother is stable.
  • Active bleeding or reaching term gestation (37 weeks or more) are key reasons to discontinue or not initiate expectant management.

questions.text: Identify type of abruption in following figure
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Assuming the figure depicted internal bleeding behind the placenta with no visible vaginal bleeding, this is the classic presentation of a concealed abruption.

Types of Abruption:

  1. Concealed Abruption: Characterized by internal bleeding behind the placenta with no visible vaginal bleeding. This type can be dangerous due to hidden blood loss and may lead to fetal distress.
  2. Revealed Abruption: Involves external bleeding visible from the vagina. This allows for better monitoring of blood loss and may prompt earlier intervention.
  3. Mixed Abruption: A combination of internal and external bleeding.

Explanation of Other Options:

Subchorionic abruption (Option B): A subchorionic abruption refers to a hemorrhage beneath the chorion, which is a common cause of bleeding in early pregnancy. While it is a type of placental detachment, it's a specific location of hemorrhage and not one of the main categories of abruption (concealed/revealed/mixed) based on visible bleeding.

Preplacental abruption (Option C): This term is not a standard classification for abruption in the same way as concealed or revealed. Abruption typically refers to the detachment of the placenta from the uterine wall.

Key Takeaways:

  • Concealed abruption is diagnosed when bleeding occurs behind the placenta but no external vaginal bleeding is visible. This can lead to significant hidden blood loss.
  • Revealed abruption involves visible vaginal bleeding.
  • The primary classification of placental abruption is based on whether the bleeding is concealed or revealed.

questions.text: A 22-year-old G2P1 at 36 weeks of gestation comes to the labour room complaining of abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her pulse is 120 bpm, BP 160/110 mmHg. Fundus reveals tenderness and FHS is 110 bpm. Most likely diagnosis in this patient would be
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, a high pulse (120 bpm), elevated blood pressure (160/110 mmHg), fundal tenderness, and fetal heart rate (FHS) of 110 bpm (suggesting fetal distress) are classic clinical features of placental abruption.

Clinical features favoring diagnosis of abruption:

  • Painful, dark red bleeding.
  • Fundus may be disproportionately large in concealed/mixed abruption.
  • Abdomen tense, tender.
  • Placenta is not felt in the lower segment.
  • Signs of fetal distress can be present.

Explanation of Other Options:

Placenta previa (Option A): Placenta previa typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding, a relaxed uterus, and usually no maternal hypertension or fetal distress (unless severe bleeding leads to shock). The patient's symptoms of pain, tenderness, and fetal distress rule out typical placenta previa.

Vasa previa (Option C): Vasa previa involves painless bleeding of fetal origin, often leading to rapid fetal distress or demise with minimal maternal symptoms initially. While fetal distress (FHS 110 bpm) is present, the associated maternal pain, uterine tenderness, and hypertension are not typical for vasa previa.

Active labour (Option D): While active labor involves contractions causing pain, the description of fundal tenderness, dark bleeding (implied by "vaginal bleeding" in abruption context), maternal hypertension, and fetal distress goes beyond the typical presentation of uncomplicated active labor. These additional symptoms strongly suggest a complication like abruption.

Key Takeaways:

  • Placental abruption is characterized by the sudden onset of painful vaginal bleeding, a tender and often rigid uterus, and signs of fetal distress.
  • The maternal vital signs (tachycardia, hypertension) and fetal status are crucial in differentiating abruption from other causes of bleeding in late pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4P3 at 32 weeks of gestation comes to the emergency room with an episode of vaginal bleeding. Her pulse is 140 bpm, BP 90/60 mmHg. Fundal height corresponds to 3 weeks and it reveals tenderness, FHS is 90 bpm. What should be the next immediate step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with a critical obstetric emergency suggestive of severe placental abruption with hypovolemic shock and fetal distress. Her symptoms include vaginal bleeding, rapid pulse (140 bpm), low blood pressure (90/60 mmHg), uterine tenderness, and fetal bradycardia (FHS 90 bpm). In such a life-threatening situation for both mother and fetus, the immediate priority is always maternal stabilization through resuscitation and volume replacement.

  • Management in case of abruption depends on:
    • Amount of blood loss and maternal condition
    • Maturity of the fetus
    • Whether the patient is in labor or not (labor usually starts)
    • Presence of any complication
    • Type and grade of placental abruption
  • Immediate management: Stabilization of the mother.
  • Definitive management: Delivery of the fetus.

Explanation of Other Options:

TVS and localization of placenta (Option A): While ultrasound is important, in a patient who is hemodynamically unstable and shows signs of severe abruption and fetal distress, delaying resuscitation for an ultrasound is not the immediate priority. Resuscitation takes precedence.

ARM + oxytocin (Option B): Artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and oxytocin are methods of inducing or augmenting labor, which might be considered later for delivery but only after the mother's condition is stabilized. Performing these actions immediately in an unstable patient can worsen her condition and is contraindicated without prior stabilization.

Immediate Cesarean section (Option D): Immediate Cesarean section is the definitive treatment for severe abruption with fetal distress, but it cannot be safely performed until the mother is adequately resuscitated and her hemodynamic status is stabilized. Operating on a hypotensive patient carries significant risks.

Key Takeaways:

  • In cases of severe placental abruption with maternal instability (shock) and fetal distress, the absolute immediate priority is maternal resuscitation and volume replacement.
  • Definitive management (like Cesarean section) follows stabilization.
  • Diagnostic procedures (like detailed ultrasound) and labor induction/augmentation are secondary to immediate life-saving measures.

choices.text: Can be seen with revealed abruption
Can only be diagnosed on laparotomy
It tends to occur more commonly in lower uterine segment

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about following figure
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a Couvelaire uterus (utero-placental apoplexy), which is a pathological condition characterized by massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serous coat. This condition can only be definitively diagnosed on laparotomy (during abdominal surgery), as it involves blood seeping into the uterine wall itself, which is not visible externally.

  • Couvelaire uterus is a pathological entity associated with a severe form of concealed abruptio placentae.
  • Naked eye features: The uterus is of a dark port wine color, which may be patchy or diffuse. It tends to occur initially on the cornu before spreading to other areas, more specially over the placental site. Subperitoneal petechial hemorrhages are found under the uterine peritoneum and may extend into the broad ligament.
  • It is not specifically more common in the lower uterine segment.

Explanation of Other Options:

Can be seen with revealed abruption (Option A): This statement is false. Couvelaire uterus is associated with a severe form of concealed abruptio placentae, meaning the bleeding is hidden within the uterus, causing blood to infiltrate the myometrium. It is not typically seen with revealed abruption where the blood escapes externally.

It tends to occur more commonly in lower uterine segment (Option C): This statement is false. The explanation explicitly states that it is not specifically more common in the lower uterine segment. It often starts at the cornu and spreads over the placental site.

Key Takeaways:

  • A Couvelaire uterus is a serious complication of severe concealed placental abruption.
  • Its diagnosis is primarily intraoperative (on laparotomy), as it involves blood infiltration into the uterine wall.
  • It presents as a characteristic dark, mottled appearance of the uterus.

choices.text: Allow to go in spontaneous labour

questions.text: A 31 years old, primigravida patient came for an ANC visit for routine check-up at 36 weeks of gestation. Her ultrasound done at 32 weeks suggests placenta previa. She doesn't complain of pain or bleeding per vagina. Obstetrician repeated ultrasound for placental localization, which suggested central placenta previa. What is the best plan of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For a patient at 36 weeks gestation with an uncomplicated central placenta previa (no pain or bleeding), the optimal time for delivery is around 37 weeks. Therefore, the best plan of management is a planned Cesarean section after 1 week (which would put her at 37 weeks). For women who are near term and not bleeding, plans are made for a scheduled Cesarean delivery in a controlled setting with an ICU facility.

Explanation of Other Options:

Immediate Cesarean section (Option A): An immediate Cesarean section is not necessary if the patient is stable and has no active bleeding or signs of fetal distress. Waiting until 37 weeks allows for further fetal maturation without increased risk in an uncomplicated case.

Allow to go in spontaneous labour (Option C): Allowing a patient with a confirmed central placenta previa to go into spontaneous labor is contraindicated as it would lead to severe, life-threatening hemorrhage due to placental separation from the dilating cervix.

Induction of labour (Option D): Induction of labor is contraindicated in central placenta previa for the same reasons as allowing spontaneous labor; it would initiate cervical dilation and lead to catastrophic bleeding.

Key Takeaways:

  • For uncomplicated central placenta previa near term, the management involves a planned Cesarean section around 37 weeks to optimize fetal outcome while preventing maternal complications.
  • Vaginal delivery or induction of labor is contraindicated in central placenta previa.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions vaginal examination is not done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A vaginal examination must not be done outside in cases of placenta previa. Performing a vaginal examination can provoke further separation of the placenta and lead to torrential hemorrhage, which may be fatal. It can only be done prior to termination of pregnancy in the operation theater under anesthesia, while keeping everything ready for Cesarean section.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cord prolapse (Option B): In the event of a suspected or confirmed cord prolapse, a vaginal examination is crucial and immediately performed to confirm the diagnosis, assess cervical dilation, and attempt to replace the cord or keep presenting part of the cord while preparing for immediate delivery. Therefore, it is done.

Ca cervix (Option C): A vaginal examination, including a speculum and digital examination, is essential for the diagnosis, staging, and management of cervical carcinoma (Ca cervix). While it might cause some bleeding in advanced cases, it is a necessary diagnostic and assessment tool. Therefore, it is done.

Key Takeaways:

  • A vaginal examination is contraindicated in placenta previa outside of an operating theater setting where immediate Cesarean section capabilities are available, due to the high risk of severe hemorrhage.
  • Vaginal examinations are essential for the diagnosis and management of conditions like cord prolapse and cervical carcinoma.

questions.text: All are causes of Antepartum hemorrhage (APH) except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the listed conditions can contribute to antepartum hemorrhage (APH) except for Battledore placenta. A Battledore placenta, where the umbilical cord is inserted at the edge of the placenta, is generally not associated with significant bleeding. In contrast, placenta previa, abruptio placenta, and circumvallate placenta can all lead to APH.

Explanation of Other Options:

Placenta previa (Option A): This is a major cause of APH.

Abruptio placenta (Option B): This is the most common cause of APH.

Circumvallate placenta (Option C): This is an uncommon cause of APH. Circumvallate placenta is an uncommon cause of antepartum hemorrhage. Bleeding associated with it is usually painless. In this condition, the chorionic plate which is on the fetal side of the placenta is smaller than the basal plate on the maternal side. The fetal surface of the placenta presents a central depression surrounded by a thickened grayish white ring. These pregnancies may be complicated by IUGR (intrauterine growth restriction) and an increased chance of fetal malformations.

Key Takeaways:

  • Placenta previa, abruptio placenta, and circumvallate placenta are causes of antepartum hemorrhage.
  • Battledore placenta is generally not associated with significant bleeding and is therefore not considered a cause of APH.

questions.text: Placenta previa is associated with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primigravida (a woman pregnant for the first time) is not considered a risk factor for placenta previa. Instead, increasing parity (having had previous pregnancies) is a known risk factor. Placenta previa is the implantation of the placenta partially or completely over the lower uterine segment.

Risk factors for placenta previa include:

  • Prior surgery (Cesarean section, Myomectomy, Hysterotomy). A previous Cesarean section increases the risk of placenta previa by 4 fold. (Option B ruled out)
  • Previous uterine curettage.
  • Endometritis.
  • Increasing maternal age (greater than 35 years).
  • Increasing parity.
  • Increased placental size (as in multiple pregnancy). (Option A ruled out)
  • Placental abnormality (e.g., Succenturiate lobe).
  • Smoking (due to defective decidual vascularization) - Smoking increases the risk of placenta previa by twofold.
  • Elevated prenatal maternal serum alpha fetoprotein levels (unexplained).
  • Prior history of placenta previa (Option D ruled out)

Explanation of Other Options:

Large placenta (Option A): An increased placental size (as seen in multiple pregnancy) is a risk factor for placenta previa.

Previous C. S. scar (Option B): A previous Cesarean section scar is a significant risk factor for placenta previa, increasing the risk by 4 fold. Damage to the endometrium or myometrium due to previous surgery can predispose to low implantation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Primigravida is not a risk factor for placenta previa.
  • Previous Cesarean section, large placenta, increasing maternal age, and other uterine factors are established risk factors for placenta previa.

questions.text: Expectant management of placenta previa includes all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cervical cerclage is generally not used in placenta previa. It is more commonly used in cases of cervical incompetence, not for managing placenta previa. The expectant management (also known as the McAfee and Johnson regime) of placenta previa aims to continue pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health.

Components of expectant management include:

  • Hospitalization until active bleeding stops and then readmission at 34 weeks.
  • Complete bed rest.
  • Correction of anemia with blood transfusion (if necessary); blood should always be kept ready as placenta previa is a recurrent condition. This means blood transfusion may be necessary if there is significant bleeding or if the mother experiences severe blood loss.(Option C ruled out)
  • Antenatal steroids to promote fetal lung maturity. This is used if preterm delivery is anticipated. (Option D ruled out)
  • Anti-D if the patient is Rh negative. This is to prevent Rh sensitization, especially if there is any bleeding. (Option A ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Cervical cerclage is not a component of expectant management for placenta previa.
  • Expectant management for placenta previa focuses on fetal maturity while ensuring maternal stability.
  • Key elements include hospitalization, bed rest, blood transfusion readiness, antenatal steroids, and Anti-D administration if indicated.

questions.text: A primigravida at 37 weeks of gestation reported to the labour room with central placenta previa with heavy bleeding per vaginum. The fetal heart rate was normal at the time of examination. The best management option for her is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cesarean section is the safest and best option for delivery in cases of central placenta previa with heavy bleeding. This approach avoids the significant risk of further hemorrhage and complications associated with vaginal delivery. The patient's situation (37 weeks gestation, central placenta previa, and heavy bleeding) warrants immediate termination of pregnancy.

  • The patient's gestational age is 37 weeks, meaning the fetus has attained maturity, so immediate termination of pregnancy is recommended.
  • The patient is experiencing heavy bleeding, which further warrants immediate delivery.
  • She has central placenta previa (Type IV), which contraindicates vaginal delivery.
  • According to Fernando Arias, "In patients with heavy bleeding an efficient management plan including life support measures and immediate operative intervention is the only way to avoid a maternal death." It further states, "Patients with placenta previa and severe bleeding should be delivered by cesarean section irrespective of the type of placenta previa."

Explanation of Other Options:

Expectant management (Option A): This is not appropriate in the setting of heavy bleeding with placenta previa, as it poses significant risks to both the mother and fetus. Expectant management is typically reserved for stable patients with less severe bleeding at earlier gestations.

Induction and vaginal delivery (Option C): This is contraindicated in placenta previa, especially central type, because the risk of severe bleeding and potential harm to both mother and fetus during vaginal delivery is extremely high.

Induction and forceps delivery (Option D): This is also contraindicated for similar reasons as induction alone; forceps delivery would not be suitable given the placenta previa and the inherent risk of severe bleeding.

Key Takeaways:

  • Central placenta previa with heavy bleeding at term is an absolute indication for immediate Cesarean section.
  • Vaginal delivery, induction of labor, or expectant management are all contraindicated in this emergency scenario.

choices.text: Higher incidence in women with lower segment cesarean section

questions.text: All of the following are true of placenta previa except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The statement that placenta previa causes first trimester bleeding is false. Placenta previa is defined as a cause of Antepartum Hemorrhage (APH), which means bleeding from or into the genital tract after the 28th week of pregnancy but before the birth of the baby. It is more commonly associated with bleeding in the second and third trimesters. First trimester bleeding is usually due to other causes such as implantation bleeding or early pregnancy complications like abortion or ectopic pregnancy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Malposition and malpresentation are common (Option B): This is true. Placenta previa can lead to abnormal fetal positions or presentations because the placenta's location can restrict the fetal head from engaging properly in the pelvis.

Premature labour is common (Option C): This is also true. Placenta previa increases the risk of preterm labor due to the risk of bleeding and complications that might necessitate early delivery.

Higher incidence in women with lower segment Cesarean section (Option D): This is true. Women who have had a lower segment Cesarean section are at higher risk for placenta previa in subsequent pregnancies, likely due to scarring and changes in the uterine structure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Placenta previa is a cause of late pregnancy bleeding (second and third trimesters), not first trimester bleeding.
  • It is associated with fetal malposition/malpresentation, increased risk of premature labor, and a higher incidence in women with previous Cesarean sections.

questions.text: Abruptio placentae occurs in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alcoholism is not typically listed as a direct risk factor for abruptio placentae. While heavy alcohol use during pregnancy can lead to various complications, placental abruption is not a commonly associated direct risk. Abruptio placentae is the premature separation of a normally situated placenta, resulting in hemorrhage.

Risk factors for abruptio placentae include:

  • Increased maternal age
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Preterm ruptured membranes pregnancy
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Cocaine abuse
  • External trauma
  • Uterine leiomyoma
  • Increased parity
  • Chronic hypertension
  • Sudden uterine decompression (as in hydramnios and twin pregnancy)
  • Thrombophilia
  • Previous abruption
  • Folic acid deficiency

Explanation of Other Options:

Smokers (Option A): Cigarette smoking is a known risk factor for abruptio placentae.

Cocaine use (Option C): Cocaine abuse is a strong risk factor for abruptio placentae, often leading to acute vasoconstriction and placental ischemia.

Advanced maternal age (Option D): Increased maternal age is also a recognized risk factor for abruptio placentae.

Key Takeaways:

  • While various factors increase the risk of abruptio placentae, alcoholism is not typically identified as a direct cause.
  • Key risk factors include smoking, cocaine use, advanced maternal age, pre-eclampsia, and chronic hypertension.

questions.text: Commonly used grading for abruption placenta:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Page classification (proposed by Page in 1951) is the commonly used clinical grading system for abruptio placentae (accidental hemorrhage). It remains a very practical, useful, and quick bedside assessment tool for the patient.

  • Clinical classification of placental abruption was suggested by Page in 1951 and still continues to be a very practical, useful, and quick bedside assessment of the patient.
  • Another classification for abruption was proposed by Sher in 1978.

Explanation of Other Options:

Johnson (Option B): While Johnson's name is associated with Mcafee in the expectant management of placenta previa, Johnson is not a commonly used grading system for abruption placenta.

Mcafee (Option C): Mcafee is associated with the expectant management regime for placenta previa, not a grading system for abruption placenta.

Apt (Option D): The Apt test is a diagnostic test used to differentiate between fetal and maternal blood in cases of vaginal bleeding, particularly relevant in suspected vasa previa, but it is not a grading system for abruption placenta.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Page classification is the widely recognized clinical grading system for abruptio placentae.
  • Other terms like Johnson, Mcafee, and Apt refer to different obstetric concepts or tests, not abruption grading.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G3P2 woman at 34 weeks gestation is involved in a serious car accident in which she lost consciousness briefly. In the emergency department she is awake and alert and complains of a severe headache and intense abdominal and pelvic pain. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate is 120/min, temperature is 37.4C (99.3F), and respiratory rate is 22/min. Fetal heart rate is 155/min. Physical examination reveals several minor bruises on her abdomen and limbs, and vaginal inspection reveals blood in the vault. Strong, frequent uterine contractions are palpable. Which of the following is most likely a complication of this pts present condition:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient presents with severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions after trauma, strongly suggestive of placental abruption.
  • Placental abruption leads to release of tissue factor (thromboplastin) from decidual and placental tissue into maternal circulation.
  • This activates the coagulation cascade, consuming clotting factors and platelets → disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • DIC is therefore the most serious immediate complication of placental abruption.

Explanation of other options:
IUGR (Option B): Chronic placental insufficiency may cause IUGR, but this is a long-term complication. The question stem is about acute complication.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Option C): Caused by vascular rupture in the brain, unrelated to abruption.

Vasa previa (Option D): Involves fetal vessels crossing the cervical os and leads to fetal exsanguination after membrane rupture, not maternal DIC.

Key Takeaways:

  • Placental abruption presents with painful vaginal bleeding, uterine hypertonicity, and contractions.
  • Major acute complication is DIC, due to release of thromboplastin.
  • Chronic sequelae like IUGR are possible but not immediate threats.

choices.text: Mortality rate of 20% with undiagnosed case

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vasa previa except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vasa previa is a rare condition where fetal vessels traverse the fetal membranes across the cervical osunprotected by placenta or umbilical cord.
  • Incidence: ~1 in 2000-5000 pregnancies (so incidence 1:2000 is correct).
  • Mortality: If undiagnosed, perinatal mortality can be as high as 20-60%, so mortality rate of 20% with undiagnosed case is true.
  • Management: Cesarean section is the mode of delivery to prevent vessel rupture during labor.
  • Association: Vasa previa is associated with velamentous cord insertion and succenturiate/bilobed placenta, not with low-lying placenta. This makes the statement "associated with low lying placenta" false.

Explanation of other options:

Incidence is 1:2000 (Option A): Correct, matches reported incidence range.

Mortality rate of 20% with undiagnosed case (Option B): Correct, reflects the high perinatal risk due to unprotected vessel rupture.

Cesarean section is indicated (Option D): Correct, C-section prevents fetal exsanguination.

Key Takeaways:

  • Vasa previa = fetal vessels crossing internal os, prone to rupture during labor.
  • Risk factors: Velamentous cord insertion, succenturiate lobe.
  • Management: Planned cesarean delivery before labor.

questions.text: Which test differentiates maternal and fetal blood cell?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Both Apt test and Kleihauer-Betke test can be used to detect the presence of fetal blood within a sample. Apt Test/Singers Alkali Denaturation Test:

  • Used to detect the presence or absence of fetal blood (qualitative) in a vaginal discharge to rule out vasa previa in pregnancy.

Kleihauer-Betke Test:

  • The sample is maternal peripheral smear and is used to see how much of fetal blood (quantitative) has been transfused into the maternal serum in order to assess the risk of isoimmunization and then the risk of hemolytic disease of newborn

Both of them rely on the fact that HbF is resistant to alkali (Apt) and acids (Kleihauer-Betke) and so the HbA containing RBCs (Maternal) will be hemolyzed but not the fetal RBCs as they have the HbF.

When the amount of fetal bleeding needs to be estimated Kleihauer-Betke test is used (Quantitative estimation). When fetal RBC is to be differentiated from maternal RBC-APT test is used.

Explanation of other options:

Kleihauer test (Option B): Acid elution test used for quantifying the amount of fetal RBCs in maternal circulation(important for calculating Rh immunoglobulin dose), but it does not directly distinguish source in neonatal samples.

Bubble test (Option C): Used for assessing surfactant presence in amniotic fluid for fetal lung maturity, not related to differentiating maternal vs fetal blood.

Lilly's test (Option D): Amniotic fluid test to detect meconium staining, not relevant to blood differentiation.

Key Takeaways:

  • APT test → differentiates maternal vs fetal blood.
  • Kleihauer test → quantifies fetomaternal hemorrhage.
  • Other listed tests are unrelated to blood source determination.

questions.text: A 26 years old female suffers from PPH on her second postnatal day. Her APTT and PTT are prolonged while BT, PT and platelet counts are normal.Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This means the patient is suffering from hemophilia. The question now arises whether it is acquired or inherited/congenital hemophilia.

Inherited congenital hemophilia:

  • Is extremely rare in females.
  • It is an x linked disorder seen mainly in males.

Acquired hemophilia

  • It is a disorder in which antibodies develop against coagulation factors.
  • Antibodies can develop against one coagulation factor or several factors.
  • The most common target protein is factor VIII.
  • Anti-factor VIII antibodies are seen in:
    • Hemophiliacs (apart from the congenital factor VIII or IX deficiency)
    • Postpartum females
    • Due to drugs
    • SLE
    • Normal elderly individuals
  • The patient in the question is a post - partum female who has developed antibodies against factor VIII (i.e. she is a case of Acquired hemophilia).
  • The patients coagulation profile matches exactly with that of acquired hemophilia confirming our diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:
Lupus anticoagulant (Option B): Prolongs APTT but is paradoxically associated with thrombosis and not bleeding. Hence ruled out.

DIC (Option C): Would present with prolonged PT, prolonged APTT, thrombocytopenia, and increased BT with evidence of microangiopathic hemolysis. Here PT, BT, and platelet count are normal → not DIC.

Inherited congenital hemophilia (Option D): Presents with lifelong history of bleeding, not suddenly in postpartum period. Also, it usually manifests in males (X-linked).

Key Takeaways:

  • Isolated prolonged APTT with bleeding → factor VIII inhibitor (acquired hemophilia).
  • Lupus anticoagulant causes clotting, not bleeding.
  • DIC affects multiple parameters (PT, APTT, platelets, BT).
  • Congenital hemophilia presents earlier in life and usually in males.

questions.text: At 28 weeks on USG-(TVS) a G2P1 female was detected as having major placenta previa. A confirmatory scan should be performed:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Placenta previa diagnosed in the second trimester or early third trimester often resolves due to placental migration (placenta moves upward as uterus enlarges).
  • Hence, a repeat scan is needed to confirm persistence.
  • Transvaginal sonography (TVS) is the most accurate modality.
  • Timing: Recommended confirmatory scan at 32 weeks because by this time, placental migration would have occurred if it is going to happen, and persistence beyond this age has clinical significance.
  • Early confirmation (before 32 weeks) can give false diagnosis, while later confirmation delays management planning.

Explanation of other options:

At 34 weeks (Option B): Too late, as diagnosis and delivery planning should already be established by then.

At 36 weeks (Option C): Very late, as patient may already go into labor before diagnosis is reconfirmed.

At onset of labor (Option D): Unsafe; waiting till labor increases the risk of sudden hemorrhage and maternal-fetal complications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Placenta previa diagnosed before 32 weeks may resolve spontaneously.
  • Confirmatory scan for major placenta previa should be performed at 32 weeks by TVS.
  • This timing balances between avoiding false positives and ensuring timely peripartum planning.
